steps.description: This walkthrough shows where every piece of the `Schnorr-signature` module lives, so you always know which file to open next.
Everything a caller can legally see is declared here. The **guard** and the **BIP-340** comment mark it as the public entry point.
Typical high-level primitive (`sign32`). The header exposes **API**, *never* implementation.
The build system confirms the `header`’s special status: it is the only file installed with the **library**.
Real code hides in `main_impl.h`. Note the **private include guard** and the fact that it re-includes the `public header` to keep prototypes in sync.
`main_impl.h` is **inlined** into the monolithic `secp256k1.c` translation unit when the module is enabled, so no extra object file or symbol leakage occurs.
Inside you find the concrete bodies (here: `schnorrsig_sign32`) that fulfil the header’s contract.
`bench_impl.h` provides micro-benchmarks.  It is a learning tool, not part of production binaries.
`tests_impl.h` hosts unit tests and BIP-340 vectors, perfect for exploring edge cases and expected behaviour.
`tests_exhaustive_impl.h` performs a full group-order sweep – heavy, slow, and invaluable for deep protocol study.
Those three helper headers are tagged `noinst`: they build only in the test/bench targets, never in production.

File map recap:
- `include/secp256k1_schnorrsig.h` – sole public surface.
- `src/modules/schnorrsig/main_impl.h` – all implementation, pulled into `secp256k1.c`.
- `bench_impl.h`, `tests_impl.h`, `tests_exhaustive_impl.h` – not shipped, but excellent reading material.
With this map you can dive straight to the level of detail you need.
